summary: the nucleocapsid protein (NP) of SARS-CoV may be critical for pathogenicity. the proteasome subunit p42 is a subunit of the 26S proteasome. p42 is a subunit of the 26S proteasome. the mechanism of the serious damage to the respiratory system caused by SARS-CoV remains unclear. at least two possibilities exist: (i) direct damage to cells and tissues by the SARS-CoV and (ii) indirect damage. antibodies against the nucleocapsid protein are longer lived and occur in greater abundance in SARS patients. this may be due to the presence of higher levels of nucleocapsid protein, compared with other viral proteins, after SARS-CoV infection [11]. PCR products were purified and cloned into the pGEX-5X-1 plasmid (Pharmacia, GE) using XhoI/EcoRI, to generate pGEX-5X-1-p42. the plasmid pcDNA3.0-SNP22b was subcloned into pcDNA3.0 (Invitrogen) all recombinant clones were confirmed by sequencing. 2CO3, 35 mM NaHCO3, pH 9.6) overnight at 4°C. plates were washed with PBST (100 mM NaCl, 10 mM Na2HPO4, 3 mM KH2PO4, 0.05% (v/v) fat-free milk in PBST for 1 h. all wells were incubated at 37°C for 1 h, followed by washing six times with PBST. expression, identification, and purification of recombinant SARS-CoV NP Plasmid pET22b-SNP22b was transformed into E. coli BL21. fusion protein SNP-His was expressed under 1 mM IPTG for 12 h. pellets were lysed in 700 L lysis buffer (1% Nonidet P40 and 20 L protease inhibitor cocktail set III) in 1 mL HBS-EP Buffer (pH 7.4, BIAcore) followed by freezing at -70°C and thawing at room temperature three times. supernatant was collected, aliquoted, and stored at -70°C. gel stained using modified Neuhoff's colloidal Coomassie blue G-250 stain solution. protein bands of interest were cut out of the gel and rinsed twice in 50% (v/v) methanol. Glutathione Sepharose 4B beads (Pharmacia, GE) were suspended in lysis buffer to a concentration of 50% (w/v) lysates of E. coli expressing the p42-GST fusion protein were added into three tubes. lysates of E. coli expressing GST alone, and lysis buffer represented the test sample, negative control, and blank control respectively. coverslips were washed six times with 1 PBS at 37°C for 60 min. after incubation with 1:80 dilution of goat anti-rabbit IgG-FITC (Sigma) and 1:200 dilution of goat anti-mouse IgG-TRITC (Sigma) conjugates, coverslips were again washed six times with 1 PBS. plasmid pcDNA3.0-SNP22b was constructed by subcloning the SNP gene into pcDNA3.0 (Invitrogen) all of the recombinant clones were confirmed by sequencing. all wells were incubated at 37°C for 1 h, followed by washing six times with PBST. all wells were incubated with anti-SARS-CoV NP horse polyclonal antibody-HRP conjugate for 1 h at 37°C. fusion protein SNP-His was expressed under 1 mM IPTG at 22°C for 12 h. Bacteria were harvested and lyzed in lysis buffer (1 mg/mL lysozyme (Sigma), 1% (v/v) Triton X-100, 5 g/mL DNAse, 5 g/mL RNAse) at 4°C for 30 min. a sensor chip CM5 flow cell was activated with 70 L of a mixture of EDC/NHS, SARS-CoV NP (70 L, 80 g/mL) injected, and the flow cell was blocked using ethanolamine (70 L, 1 M) a flow cell immobilized with SARS-CoV NP functioned as the blank control. modified Neuhoff's colloidal Coomassie blue G-250 stain solution. protein bands of interest were cut out of the gel and rinsed twice in 50% (v/v) methanol. in-gel digestion was performed using sequencing-grade modified trypsin. 42-GST fusion protein (1 mL), lysates of E. coli expressing GST alone, and lysis buffer represented the test sample, negative control, and blank control. the remaining mixture was washed three times in cold lysis buffer (200 L), to which was added purified SARS-CoV NP (100 L) and the mixture was further incubated at 4°C. dilution of goat anti-mouse IgG-TRITC conjugates at 37°C for 45 min. coverslips were again washed six times in distilled water and air-dried. expression of SARS-CoV NP was confirmed by SDS-PAGE. the position of SARS-CoV NP (47 kDa) is indicated by an arrow. Western blot analysis of SARS-CoV NP using an anti-SARS-CoV NP horse polyclonal antibody. Lysate of E. coli BL21 expressing SARS-CoV NP, induced by IPTG (lane 1). a stable level (1120 RU) was achieved after a total of 70 L 2BS cell lysate was injected. the flow cell was then washed six times and NaOH (5 L, 50 mM) was injected to elute proteins bound to SARS-CoV NP. the specific reaction of SARS-CoV NP and 2BS cell lysate was quantified as 1056 RU. no protein was captured from the blank or negative controls. analysis by MALID-TOF mass spectrometry identified the proteins as 26S proteasome regulatory subunit S10B. cytokeratin 1 (CK1) has the highest molecular weight and highest isoelectric point of the family. SARS-CoV NP exhibits a specific interaction with the proteasome subunit p42 in vitro. these data suggest that SARS-CoV NP exhibit a specific interaction with the proteasome subunit p42 in vitro. SARS-CoV NP-SNP22b (positive control; lane 6), bead + GST lysate (lane 4), p42-GST fusion protein bacterial lysate (lane 9). position of SARS-CoV NP is indicated by an arrow. expression of SARS-CoV NP in 2BS cells was confirmed using an anti-sARS-CoV NP mAb. SARS-CoV NP was expressed in 2BS cells transfected with -pcDNA3.0+SNP22b. proteasome subunit p42 in 2BS cells localized with anti-p42 antibody and anti-rabbit IgG-FITC conjugate, excitation at 488 nm (lane 1). expression, identification and purification of SARS-CoV NP was confirmed by SDS-PAGE. supernatants (lanes 3 and 7) and pellets (lanes 4 and 8) of E. coli BL21 containing the pET22b-SNP22b vector induced with IPTG. Pellets of E. coli BL21 containing pET22b induced with IPTG (lane 5). Molecular weight markers (lane 9) position of SARS-CoV NP (47 kDa) is indicated by an arrow. immobilization of SARS-CoV NP in a sensor chip CM5 flow cell resulted in an RU value of 12355.1. a stable level (1120 RU) was achieved after a total of 70 L 2BS cell lysate was injected. the flow cell was then washed six times and NaOH (5 L, 50 mM) was injected to elute proteins bound to SARS-CoV NP. the protein(s) captured by SARS-CoV NP were precipitated, resolved by 1D SDS-PAGE and visualized using modified Coomassie blue G-250 staining. no protein was captured from the blank or negative controls (lane 3). interaction of SARS-CoV NP with proteasome subunit p42 in vitro was identified using an anti-GST mAb. data suggested that the SARS-CoV NP was pulled down by p42-GST fusion protein (Fig. 4, lanes 6, 8) but not by either of the negative controls. Western blot analysis of the interaction between p42-GST fusion protein and SARS-CoV NP in vitro. bead + lysis buffer + NP (lane 1), bead + lysis buffer (lane 2), bead + GST lysate + NP (lane 3), bead + GST lysate (lane 3), p42-GST fusion protein bacterial lysate (lane 9). p42 and p42 in 2BS cells were elucidated by merging lane 1 and lane 2 of Fig 4. p42 was expressed in 2BS cells transfected with recombinant -pcDNA3.0+SNP22b. proteasome subunit p42 was detected in 2BS cells. proinflammatory cytokines released by macrophages in pulmonary alveoli play an important role in the pathogenesis of SARS. apoptosis of T- and B-lymphocytes in the immune organs and pulmonary alveoli and mononuclear inflammatory infiltration in the lungs and spleens of SARS-CoV infected individuals has been observed. proteasome subunit p42 is a subunit of PA700 in the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. this pathway mediates ATP-dependent degradation of ubiquitinated proteins. ubiquitin-proteasome pathway mediates turnover of intracellular proteins. proteasomes do hydrolyze endogenous proteins, but are also capable of degrading exogenous proteins. HBX expression inhibited turnover of c-Jun and ubiquitin- arginine-galactosidase. HBX expression inhibited turnover of c-Jun and ubiquitin- arginine-galactosidase. development of a specific inhibitor of the UPP may have potential as an antiviral, but also as an anti-tumor and anti-inflammatory agent. study of interactions of components of the UPP with viral proteins may provide useful information relating to the pathogenesis of a number of diseases. if SARS-CoV NP interacts with proteasome subunit p42 in vivo remains unknown. further studies are required to fully determine the nature of this interaction and its effect in vivo. this finding may lead to a new direction in research focusing on the molecular mechanisms of SARS-CoV infection. authors declare that they have no competing interests. authors' contributions QW and DL participated in the design. authors read and approved the final manuscript.
